64 double BOGUS_amplitude(double mpy, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
65  Station_Data *pmsd = pIDX->pref_sta_data;
66 
67  if (!pmsd->have_BOGUS) // || !convert_BOGUS) // Added mgh
68  return (mpy * pIDX->max_amplitude);
69  else {
70  if (mpy >= 0.0)
71  return (sqrt(mpy * pIDX->max_amplitude));
72  else
73  return (-sqrt(-mpy * pIDX->max_amplitude));
74  }
75 }

77 /* Calculate the denormalized tide. */
78 double time2atide(time_t t, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
79  return BOGUS_amplitude(time2tide(t, pIDX), pIDX) + pIDX->pref_sta_data->DATUM;
80 }

82 /* Next high tide, low tide, transition of the mark level, or some
83  * combination.
84  * Bit Meaning
85  * 0 low tide
86  * 1 high tide
87  * 2 falling transition
88  * 3 rising transition
89  */
90 int next_big_event(time_t *tm, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
91  double p, q;
92  int flags = 0, slope = 0;
93  p = time2atide(*tm, pIDX);
94  *tm += 60;
95  q = time2atide(*tm, pIDX);
96  *tm += 60;
97  if (p < q) slope = 1;
98  while (1) {
99  if ((slope == 1 && q < p) || (slope == 0 && p < q)) {
100  /* Tide event */
101  flags |= (1 << slope);
102  }
103  /* Modes in which to return mark transitions: */
104  /* -text (no -graph) */
105  /* -graph (no -text) */
106  /* -ppm */
107  /* -gif */
108  /* -ps */
109 
110  // if (mark && ((text && !graphmode) || (!text && graphmode)
111  // || ppm || gif || ps))
112  // int marklev = 0;
113 #if (0)
114  if (0)
115  if ((p > marklev && q <= marklev) || (p < marklev && q >= marklev)) {
116  /* Transition event */
117  if (p < q)
118  flags |= 8;
119  else
120  flags |= 4;
121  if (!(flags & 3)) {
122  /* If we're incredibly unlucky, we could miss a tide event if we
123  * don't check for it here:
124  *
125  * . <---- Value that would be
126  * returned
127  * ----------- Mark level
128  * . .
129  */
130  p = q;
131  q = time2atide(*tm, pIDX);
132  if ((slope == 1 && q < p) || (slope == 0 && p < q)) {
133  /* Tide event */
134  flags |= (1 << slope);
135  }
136  }
137  }
138 #endif
139 
140  if (flags) {
141  *tm -= 60;
142  /* Don't back up over a transition event, but do back up to where the
143  * tide changed if possible. If they happen at the same
144  * time, then we're off by a minute on the tide, but if we back it up it
145  * will get snagged on the transition event over and over. */
146  if (flags < 4) *tm -= 60;
147  return flags;
148  }
149  p = q;
150  q = time2atide(*tm, pIDX);
151  *tm += 60;
152  }
153 }
154 
155 /* Estimate the normalized mean tide level around a particular time by
156  * summing only the long-term constituents. */
157 /* Does not do any blending around year's end. */
158 /* This is used only by time2asecondary for finding the mean tide level */
159 double time2mean(time_t t, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
160  double tide = 0.0;
161  int a;
162  int new_year = yearoftimet(t);
163  if (pIDX->epoch_year != new_year) happy_new_year(pIDX, new_year);
164 
165  for (a = 0; a < pIDX->num_csts; a++) {
166  if (pIDX->m_cst_speeds[a] < 6e-6) {
167  tide += pIDX->m_work_buffer[a] *
168  cos(pIDX->m_cst_speeds[a] * ((long)(t - pIDX->epoch) +
169  pIDX->pref_sta_data->meridian) +
170  pIDX->m_cst_epochs[a][pIDX->epoch_year - pIDX->first_year] -
171  pIDX->pref_sta_data->epoch[a]);
172  }
173  }
174 
175  return tide;
176 }
177 
178 /* If offsets are in effect, interpolate the 'corrected' denormalized
179  * tide. The normalized is derived from this, instead of the other way
180  * around, because the application of height offsets requires the
181  * denormalized tide. */
182 double time2asecondary(time_t t, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
183  time_t tadj = t + pIDX->station_tz_offset;
184 
185  /* Get rid of the normals. */
186  if (!(pIDX->have_offsets)) return time2atide(tadj, pIDX);
187 
188  {
189  /* Intervalwidth of 14 (was originally 13) failed on this input:
190  * -location Dublon -hloff +0.0001 -gstart 1997:09:10:00:00 -raw
191  * 1997:09:15:00:00
192  */
193 #define intervalwidth 15
194 #define stretchfactor 3
195 
196  static time_t lowtime = 0, hightime = 0;
197  static double lowlvl, highlvl; /* Normalized tide levels for MIN, MAX */
198  time_t T; /* Adjusted t */
199  double S, Z, HI, HS, magicnum;
200  time_t interval = 3600 * intervalwidth;
201  long difflow, diffhigh;
202  int badlowflag = 0, badhighflag = 0;
203 
204  /* Algorithm by Jean-Pierre Lapointe (scipur@collegenotre-dame.qc.ca) */
205  /* as interpreted, munged, and implemented by DWF */
206 
207  /* This is the initial guess (average of time offsets) */
208  // T = t - (httimeoff + lttimeoff) / 2;
209  T = tadj - (pIDX->IDX_ht_time_off * 60 + pIDX->IDX_lt_time_off * 60) / 2;
210  /* The usage of an estimate of mean tide level here is to correct
211  * for seasonal changes in tide level. Previously I had simply
212  * used the zero of the tide function as the mean, but this gave bad results
213  * around summer and winter for locations with large seasonal variations. */
214  // printf("-----time2asecondary %ld %ld %d %d\n", t, T,
215  // pIDX->IDX_ht_time_off ,pIDX->IDX_lt_time_off);
216 
217  Z = time2mean(T, pIDX);
218  S = time2tide(T, pIDX) - Z;
219 
220  /* Find MAX and MIN. I use the highest high tide and the lowest
221  * low tide over a 26 hour period, but I allow the interval to
222  * stretch a lot if necessary to avoid creating discontinuities. The
223  * heuristic used is not perfect but will hopefully be good
224  * enough.
225  *
226  * It is an assumption in the algorithm that the tide level will
227  * be above the mean tide level for MAX and below it for MIN. A
228  * changeover occurs at mean tide level. It would be nice to
229  * always use the two tides that immediately bracket T and to put
230  * the changeover at mid tide instead of always at mean tide
231  * level, since this would eliminate much of the inaccuracy.
232  * Unfortunately if you change the location of the changeover it
233  * causes the tide function to become discontinuous.
234  *
235  * Now that I'm using time2mean, the changeover does move, but so
236  * slowly that it makes no difference.
237  */
238 
239  if (lowtime < T)
240  difflow = T - lowtime;
241  else
242  difflow = lowtime - T;
243  if (hightime < T)
244  diffhigh = T - hightime;
245  else
246  diffhigh = hightime - T;
247 
248  /* Update MIN? */
249  if (difflow > interval * stretchfactor) badlowflag = 1;
250  if (badlowflag || (difflow > interval && S > 0)) {
251  time_t tt;
252  double tl;
253  tt = T - interval;
254  next_big_event(&tt, pIDX);
255  lowlvl = time2tide(tt, pIDX);
256  lowtime = tt;
257  while (tt < T + interval) {
258  next_big_event(&tt, pIDX);
259  tl = time2tide(tt, pIDX);
260  if (tl < lowlvl && tt < T + interval) {
261  lowlvl = tl;
262  lowtime = tt;
263  }
264  }
265  }
266  /* Update MAX? */
267  if (diffhigh > interval * stretchfactor) badhighflag = 1;
268  if (badhighflag || (diffhigh > interval && S < 0)) {
269  time_t tt;
270  double tl;
271  tt = T - interval;
272  next_big_event(&tt, pIDX);
273  highlvl = time2tide(tt, pIDX);
274  hightime = tt;
275  while (tt < T + interval) {
276  next_big_event(&tt, pIDX);
277  tl = time2tide(tt, pIDX);
278  if (tl > highlvl && tt < T + interval) {
279  highlvl = tl;
280  hightime = tt;
281  }
282  }
283  }
284 
285 #if 0
286  /* UNFORTUNATELY there are times when the tide level NEVER CROSSES
287  * THE MEAN for extended periods of time. ARRRGH! */
288  if (lowlvl >= 0.0)
289  lowlvl = -1.0;
290  if (highlvl <= 0.0)
291  highlvl = 1.0;
292 #endif
293  /* Now that I'm using time2mean, I should be guaranteed to get
294  * an appropriate low and high. */
295 
296  /* Improve the initial guess. */
297  if (S > 0)
298  magicnum = 0.5 * S / fabs(highlvl - Z);
299  else
300  magicnum = 0.5 * S / fabs(lowlvl - Z);
301  // T = T - magicnum * (httimeoff - lttimeoff);
302  T = T - (time_t)(magicnum * ((pIDX->IDX_ht_time_off * 60) -
303  (pIDX->IDX_lt_time_off * 60)));
304  HI = time2tide(T, pIDX);
305 
306  // Correct the amplitude offsets for BOGUS knot^2 units
307  double ht_off, lt_off;
308  if (pIDX->pref_sta_data->have_BOGUS) {
309  ht_off = pIDX->IDX_ht_off *
310  pIDX->IDX_ht_off; // Square offset in kts to adjust for kts^2
311  lt_off = pIDX->IDX_lt_off * pIDX->IDX_lt_off;
312  } else {
313  ht_off = pIDX->IDX_ht_off;
314  lt_off = pIDX->IDX_lt_off;
315  }
316 
317  /* Denormalize and apply the height offsets. */
318  HI = BOGUS_amplitude(HI, pIDX) + pIDX->pref_sta_data->DATUM;
319  {
320  double RH = 1.0, RL = 1.0, HH = 0.0, HL = 0.0;
321  RH = pIDX->IDX_ht_mpy;
322  HH = ht_off;
323  RL = pIDX->IDX_lt_mpy;
324  HL = lt_off;
325 
326  /* I patched the usage of RH and RL to avoid big ugly
327  * discontinuities when they are not equal. -- DWF */
328 
329  HS = HI * ((RH + RL) / 2 + (RH - RL) * magicnum) + (HH + HL) / 2 +
330  (HH - HL) * magicnum;
331  }
332 
333  return HS;
334  }
335 }
336 
337 /*
338  * We will need a function for tidal height as a function of time
339  * which is continuous (and has continuous first and second derivatives)
340  * for all times.
341  *
342  * Since the epochs & multipliers for the tidal constituents change
343  * with the year, the regular time2tide(t) function has small
344  * discontinuities at new years. These discontinuities really
345  * fry the fast root-finders.
346  *
347  * We will eliminate the new-years discontinuities by smoothly
348  * interpolating (or "blending") between the tides calculated with one
349  * year's coefficients, and the tides calculated with the next year's
350  * coefficients.
351  *
352  * i.e. for times near a new years, we will "blend" a tide
353  * as follows:
354  *
355  * tide(t) = tide(year-1, t)
356  * + w((t - t0) / Tblend) * (tide(year,t) - tide(year-1,t))
357  *
358  * Here: t0 is the time of the nearest new-year.
359  * tide(year-1, t) is the tide calculated using the coefficients
360  * for the year just preceding t0.
361  * tide(year, t) is the tide calculated using the coefficients
362  * for the year which starts at t0.
363  * Tblend is the "blending" time scale. This is set by
364  * the macro TIDE_BLEND_TIME, currently one hour.
365  * w(x) is the "blending function", whice varies smoothly
366  * from 0, for x < -1 to 1 for x > 1.
367  *
368  * Derivatives of the blended tide can be evaluated in terms of derivatives
369  * of w(x), tide(year-1, t), and tide(year, t). The blended tide is
370  * guaranteed to have as many continuous derivatives as w(x). */
371 
372 /* time2dt_tide(time_t t, int n)
373  *
374  * Calculate nth time derivative the normalized tide.
375  *
376  * Notes: This function does not check for changes in year.
377  * This is important to our algorithm, since for times near
378  * new years, we interpolate between the tides calculated
379  * using one years coefficients, and the next years coefficients.
380  *
381  * Except for this detail, time2dt_tide(t,0) should return a value
382  * identical to time2tide(t).
383  */
384 double _time2dt_tide(time_t t, int deriv, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
385  double dt_tide = 0.0;
386  int a, b;
387  double term, tempd;
388 
389  tempd = M_PI / 2.0 * deriv;
390  for (a = 0; a < pIDX->num_csts; a++) {
391  term = pIDX->m_work_buffer[a] *
392  cos(tempd +
393  pIDX->m_cst_speeds[a] *
394  ((long)(t - pIDX->epoch) + pIDX->pref_sta_data->meridian) +
395  pIDX->m_cst_epochs[a][pIDX->epoch_year - pIDX->first_year] -
396  pIDX->pref_sta_data->epoch[a]);
397  for (b = deriv; b > 0; b--) term *= pIDX->m_cst_speeds[a];
398  dt_tide += term;
399  }
400  return dt_tide;
401 }
402 
403 /* blend_weight (double x, int deriv)
404  *
405  * Returns the value nth derivative of the "blending function" w(x):
406  *
407  * w(x) = 0, for x <= -1
408  *
409  * w(x) = 1/2 + (15/16) x - (5/8) x^3 + (3/16) x^5,
410  * for -1 < x < 1
411  *
412  * w(x) = 1, for x >= 1
413  *
414  * This function has the following desirable properties:
415  *
416  * w(x) is exactly either 0 or 1 for |x| > 1
417  *
418  * w(x), as well as its first two derivatives are continuous for all x.
419  */
420 static double blend_weight(double x, int deriv) {
421  double x2 = x * x;
422 
423  if (x2 >= 1.0) return deriv == 0 && x > 0.0 ? 1.0 : 0.0;
424 
425  switch (deriv) {
426  case 0:
427  return ((3.0 * x2 - 10.0) * x2 + 15.0) * x / 16.0 + 0.5;
428  case 1:
429  return ((x2 - 2.0) * x2 + 1.0) * (15.0 / 16.0);
430  case 2:
431  return (x2 - 1.0) * x * (15.0 / 4.0);
432  }
433  return (0); // mgh+ to get rid of compiler warning
434 }
435 
436 /*
437  * This function does the actual "blending" of the tide
438  * and its derivatives.
439  */
440 double blend_tide(time_t t, unsigned int deriv, int first_year, double blend,
441  IDX_entry *pIDX) {
442  double fl[TIDE_MAX_DERIV + 1];
443  double fr[TIDE_MAX_DERIV + 1];
444  double *fp = fl;
445  double w[TIDE_MAX_DERIV + 1];
446  double fact = 1.0;
447  double f;
448  unsigned int n;
449 
450  /*
451  * If we are already happy_new_year()ed into one of the two years
452  * of interest, compute that years tide values first.
453  */
454  int year = yearoftimet(t);
455  if (year == first_year + 1)
456  fp = fr;
457  else if (year != first_year)
458  happy_new_year(pIDX, first_year);
459  for (n = 0; n <= deriv; n++) fp[n] = _time2dt_tide(t, n, pIDX);
460 
461  /*
462  * Compute tide values for the other year of interest,
463  * and the needed values of w(x) and its derivatives.
464  */
465  if (fp == fl) {
466  happy_new_year(pIDX, first_year + 1);
467  fp = fr;
468  } else {
469  happy_new_year(pIDX, first_year);
470  fp = fl;
471  }
472  for (n = 0; n <= deriv; n++) {
473  fp[n] = _time2dt_tide(t, n, pIDX);
474  w[n] = blend_weight(blend, n);
475  }
476 
477  /*
478  * Do the blending.
479  */
480 
481  f = fl[deriv];
482  for (n = 0; n <= deriv; n++) {
483  f += fact * w[n] * (fr[deriv - n] - fl[deriv - n]);
484  fact *= (double)(deriv - n) / (n + 1) * (1.0 / TIDE_BLEND_TIME);
485  }
486  printf(" %ld %g %g %g %g\n", (long)t, blend, fr[0], fl[0], f);
487  return f;
488 }
489 
490 double time2dt_tide(time_t t, int deriv, IDX_entry *pIDX) {
491  int new_year;
492  int yott = yearoftimet(t);
493  new_year = yott;
494 
495  /* Make sure our values of next_epoch and epoch are up to date. */
496  if (new_year != s_this_year) {
497  if (new_year + 1 < pIDX->first_year + pIDX->num_epochs) {
498  set_epoch(pIDX, new_year + 1);
499  s_next_epoch = pIDX->epoch;
500  } else
501  s_next_epoch = TIDE_BAD_TIME;
502 
503  happy_new_year(pIDX, s_this_year = new_year);
504  s_this_epoch = pIDX->epoch;
505  }
506 
507  /*
508  * If we're close to either the previous or the next
509  * new years we must blend the two years tides.
510  */
511  if (t - s_this_epoch <= TIDE_BLEND_TIME && s_this_year > pIDX->first_year)
512  return blend_tide(t, deriv, s_this_year - 1,
513  (double)(t - s_this_epoch) / TIDE_BLEND_TIME, pIDX);
514  else if (s_next_epoch - t <= TIDE_BLEND_TIME &&
515  s_this_year + 1 < pIDX->first_year + pIDX->num_epochs)
516  return blend_tide(t, deriv, s_this_year,
517  -(double)(s_next_epoch - t) / TIDE_BLEND_TIME, pIDX);
518 
519  /*
520  * Else, we're far enough from newyears to ignore the blending.
521  */
522  if (pIDX->epoch_year != new_year) happy_new_year(pIDX, new_year);
523 
524  return _time2dt_tide(t, deriv, pIDX);
525 }
526 
527 /* Figure out max amplitude over all the years in the node factors table. */
528 /* This function by Geoffrey T. Dairiki */
529 void figure_max_amplitude(IDX_entry *pIDX) {
530  int i, a;
531 
532  if (pIDX->max_amplitude == 0.0) {
533  for (i = 0; i < pIDX->num_nodes; i++) {
534  double year_amp = 0.0;
535 
536  for (a = 0; a < pIDX->num_csts; a++)
537  year_amp += pIDX->pref_sta_data->amplitude[a] * pIDX->m_cst_nodes[a][i];
538  if (year_amp > pIDX->max_amplitude) pIDX->max_amplitude = year_amp;
539  }
540  }
541 }
542 
543 /* Figure out normalized multipliers for constituents for a particular year. */
544 void figure_multipliers(IDX_entry *pIDX, int year) {
545  int a;
546 
547  figure_max_amplitude(pIDX);
548  for (a = 0; a < pIDX->num_csts; a++) {
549  pIDX->m_work_buffer[a] = pIDX->pref_sta_data->amplitude[a] *
550  pIDX->m_cst_nodes[a][year - pIDX->first_year] /
551  pIDX->max_amplitude; // BOGUS_amplitude?
552  }
553 }

555 /* This idiotic function is needed by the new tm2gmt. */
556 #define compare_int(a, b) (((int)(a)) - ((int)(b)))
557 int compare_tm(struct tm *a, struct tm *b) {
558  int temp;
559  /* printf ("A is %d:%d:%d:%d:%d:%d B is %d:%d:%d:%d:%d:%d\n",
560  * a->tm_year+1900, a->tm_mon+1, a->tm_mday, a->tm_hour,
561  * a->tm_min, a->tm_sec,
562  * b->tm_year+1900, b->tm_mon+1, b->tm_mday, b->tm_hour,
563  * b->tm_min, b->tm_sec); */
564 
565  temp = compare_int(a->tm_year, b->tm_year);
566  if (temp) return temp;
567  temp = compare_int(a->tm_mon, b->tm_mon);
568  if (temp) return temp;
569  temp = compare_int(a->tm_mday, b->tm_mday);
570  if (temp) return temp;
571  temp = compare_int(a->tm_hour, b->tm_hour);
572  if (temp) return temp;
573  temp = compare_int(a->tm_min, b->tm_min);
574  if (temp) return temp;
575  return compare_int(a->tm_sec, b->tm_sec);
576 }
577 
578 /* Convert a struct tm in GMT back to a time_t. isdst is ignored, since
579  * it never should have been needed by mktime in the first place.
580  */
581 time_t tm2gmt(struct tm *ht) {
582  time_t guess, newguess, thebit;
583  int loopcounter, compare;
584  struct tm *gt;
585 
586  guess = 0;
587  loopcounter = (sizeof(time_t) * 8) - 1;
588  thebit = ((time_t)1) << (loopcounter - 1);
589 
590  /* For simplicity, I'm going to insist that the time_t we want is
591  * positive. If time_t is signed, skip the sign bit.
592  */
593  if ((signed long)thebit < (time_t)(0)) {
594  /* You can't just shift thebit right because it propagates the sign bit. */
595  loopcounter--;
596  thebit = ((time_t)1) << (loopcounter - 1);
597  }
598 
599  for (; loopcounter; loopcounter--) {
600  newguess = guess | thebit;
601  gt = gmtime(&newguess);
602  if (NULL != gt) {
603  compare = compare_tm(gt, ht);
604  if (compare <= 0) guess = newguess;
605  }
606  thebit >>= 1;
607  }
608 
609  return guess;
610 }
611 
612 int yearoftimet(time_t t) { return ((gmtime(&t))->tm_year) + 1900; }
613 
614 /* Calculate time_t of the epoch. */
615 void set_epoch(IDX_entry *pIDX, int year) {
616  struct tm ht;
617 
618  ht.tm_year = year - 1900;
619  ht.tm_sec = ht.tm_min = ht.tm_hour = ht.tm_mon = 0;
620  ht.tm_mday = 1;
621  pIDX->epoch = tm2gmt(&ht);
622 }
623 
624 /* Re-initialize for a different year */
625 void happy_new_year(IDX_entry *pIDX, int new_year) {
626  pIDX->epoch_year = new_year;
627  figure_multipliers(pIDX, new_year);
628  set_epoch(pIDX, new_year);
629 }

636 void TCMgr::PurgeData() {
637  m_Combined_IDX_array.clear();
638 
639  // Delete all the data sources
640  m_source_array.Clear();
641 }
642 
643 TC_Error_Code TCMgr::LoadDataSources(std::vector<std::string> &sources) {
644  PurgeData();
645 
646  // Take a copy of dataset file name array
647  m_sourcefile_array.clear();
648  m_sourcefile_array = sources;
649 
650  int num_IDX = 0;
651 
652  for (auto src : sources) {
653  TCDataSource *s = new TCDataSource;
654  TC_Error_Code r = s->LoadData(src);
655  if (r != TC_NO_ERROR) {
656  wxString msg;
657  msg.Printf(_T(" Error loading Tide/Currect data source %s "),
658  src.c_str());
659  if (r == TC_FILE_NOT_FOUND)
660  msg += _T("Error Code: TC_FILE_NOT_FOUND");
661  else {
662  wxString msg1;
663  msg1.Printf(_T("Error code: %d"), r);
664  msg += msg1;
665  }
666  wxLogMessage(msg);
667  delete s;
668  } else {
669  m_source_array.Add(s);
670 
671  for (int k = 0; k < s->GetMaxIndex(); k++) {
672  IDX_entry *pIDX = s->GetIndexEntry(k);
673  pIDX->IDX_rec_num = num_IDX;
674  num_IDX++;
675  m_Combined_IDX_array.push_back(pIDX);
676  }
677  }
678  }
679 
680  bTCMReady = true;
681 
682  if (m_Combined_IDX_array.empty())
683  OCPNMessageBox(
684  NULL, _("It seems you have no tide/current harmonic data installed."),
685  _("OpenCPN Info"), wxOK | wxCENTER);
686 
687  ScrubCurrentDepths();
688  return TC_NO_ERROR;
689 }
690 
691 void TCMgr::ScrubCurrentDepths() {
692  // Process Current stations reporting values at multiple depths
693  // Identify and mark the shallowest record, as being most usable to OCPN
694  // users
695 
696  WX_DECLARE_STRING_HASH_MAP(int, currentDepth_index_hash);
697 
698  currentDepth_index_hash hash1;
699 
700  for (int i = 1; i < Get_max_IDX() + 1; i++) {
701  IDX_entry *a = (IDX_entry *)GetIDX_entry(i);
702  if (a->IDX_type == 'C') {
703  if (a->current_depth > 0) {
704  int depth_a = a->current_depth;
705 
706  // We formulate the hash map with geo-location as the keys
707  // Using "doubles" as hashmap key values is dangerous, especially
708  // cross-platform So, we a printf-ed string of lat/lon for hash key,
709  // This is relatively inefficient. but tolerable in this little used
710  // method.
711 
712  wxString key1;
713  key1.Printf("%10.6f %10.6f", a->IDX_lat, a->IDX_lon);
714 
715  currentDepth_index_hash::iterator it = hash1.find(key1);
716  if (it == hash1.end()) {
717  // Key not found, needs to be added
718  hash1[key1] = i;
719  } else {
720  // Check the depth value at the referenced index
721  // if less than the current depth, replace the hashmap value
722  IDX_entry *b = (IDX_entry *)GetIDX_entry(it->second);
723  std::string bName(b->IDX_station_name);
724  int depth_b = b->current_depth;
725  if (depth_a < depth_b) {
726  hash1[key1] = i;
727  b->b_skipTooDeep = 1; // mark deeper index to skip display
728  } else {
729  a->b_skipTooDeep = 1; // mark deeper index to skip display
730  }
731  }
732  }
733  }
734  }
735 }

737 const IDX_entry *TCMgr::GetIDX_entry(int index) const {
738  if ((unsigned int)index < m_Combined_IDX_array.size())
739  return m_Combined_IDX_array[index];
740  else
741  return NULL;
742 }

744 bool TCMgr::GetTideOrCurrent(time_t t, int idx, float &tcvalue, float &dir) {
745  // Return a sensible value of 0,0 by default
746  dir = 0;
747  tcvalue = 0;
748 
749  // Load up this location data
750  IDX_entry *pIDX = m_Combined_IDX_array[idx]; // point to the index entry
751 
752  if (!pIDX) {
753  dir = 0;
754  tcvalue = 0;
755  return false;
756  }
757 
758  if (!pIDX->IDX_Useable) {
759  dir = 0;
760  tcvalue = 0;
761  return (false); // no error, but unuseable
762  }
763 
764  if (pIDX->pDataSource) {
765  if (pIDX->pDataSource->LoadHarmonicData(pIDX) != TC_NO_ERROR) return false;
766  }
767 
768  pIDX->max_amplitude = 0.0; // Force multiplier re-compute
769  int yott = yearoftimet(t);
770 
771  happy_new_year(pIDX, yott); // Calculate new multipliers
772 
773  // Finally, calculate the tide/current
774 
775  double level = time2asecondary(t + (00 * 60), pIDX); // 300. 240
776  if (level >= 0)
777  dir = pIDX->IDX_flood_dir;
778  else
779  dir = pIDX->IDX_ebb_dir;
780 
781  tcvalue = level;
782 
783  return (true); // Got it!
784 }
785 
786 extern wxDateTime gTimeSource;
787 
788 bool TCMgr::GetTideOrCurrent15(time_t t_d, int idx, float &tcvalue, float &dir,
789  bool &bnew_val) {
790  int ret;
791  IDX_entry *pIDX = m_Combined_IDX_array[idx]; // point to the index entry
792 
793  if (!pIDX) {
794  dir = 0;
795  tcvalue = 0;
796  return false;
797  }
798 
799  // Figure out this computer timezone minute offset
800  wxDateTime this_now = gTimeSource; // wxDateTime::Now();
801  if (this_now.IsValid() == false) this_now = wxDateTime::Now();
802  wxDateTime this_gmt = this_now.ToGMT();
803  wxTimeSpan diff = this_gmt.Subtract(this_now);
804  int diff_mins = diff.GetMinutes();
805 
806  int station_offset = pIDX->IDX_time_zone;
807  if (this_now.IsDST()) station_offset += 60;
808  int corr_mins = station_offset - diff_mins;
809 
810  wxDateTime today_00 = this_now;
811  today_00.ResetTime();
812  int t_today_00 = today_00.GetTicks();
813  int t_today_00_at_station = t_today_00 - (corr_mins * 60);
814 
815  int t_at_station =
816  this_gmt.GetTicks() - (station_offset * 60) + (corr_mins * 60);
817 
818  int t_mins = (t_at_station - t_today_00_at_station) / 60;
819  int t_15s = t_mins / 15;
820 
821  if (pIDX->Valid15) // valid data available
822  {
823  int tref1 = t_today_00_at_station + t_15s * 15 * 60;
824  if (tref1 == pIDX->Valid15) {
825  tcvalue = pIDX->Value15;
826  dir = pIDX->Dir15;
827  bnew_val = false;
828  return pIDX->Ret15;
829  } else {
830  int tref = t_today_00_at_station + t_15s * 15 * 60;
831  ret = GetTideOrCurrent(tref, idx, tcvalue, dir);
832 
833  pIDX->Valid15 = tref;
834  pIDX->Value15 = tcvalue;
835  pIDX->Dir15 = dir;
836  pIDX->Ret15 = !(ret == 0);
837  bnew_val = true;
838 
839  return !(ret == 0);
840  }
841  }
842 
843  else {
844  int tref = t_today_00_at_station + t_15s * 15 * 60;
845  ret = GetTideOrCurrent(tref, idx, tcvalue, dir);
846 
847  pIDX->Valid15 = tref;
848  pIDX->Value15 = tcvalue;
849  pIDX->Dir15 = dir;
850  pIDX->Ret15 = !(ret == 0);
851  bnew_val = true;
852  }
853 
854  return !(ret == 0);
855 }
856 
857 bool TCMgr::GetTideFlowSens(time_t t, int sch_step, int idx, float &tcvalue_now,
858  float &tcvalue_prev, bool &w_t) {
859  // Return a sensible value of 0 by default
860  tcvalue_now = 0;
861  tcvalue_prev = 0;
862  w_t = false;
863 
864  // Load up this location data
865  IDX_entry *pIDX = m_Combined_IDX_array[idx]; // point to the index entry
866 
867  if (!pIDX) return false;
868 
869  if (!pIDX->IDX_Useable) return false; // no error, but unuseable
870 
871  if (pIDX->pDataSource) {
872  if (pIDX->pDataSource->LoadHarmonicData(pIDX) != TC_NO_ERROR) return false;
873  }
874 
875  pIDX->max_amplitude = 0.0; // Force multiplier re-compute
876  int yott = yearoftimet(t);
877  happy_new_year(pIDX, yott); // Force new multipliers
878 
879  // Finally, process the tide flow sens
880 
881  tcvalue_now = time2asecondary(t, pIDX);
882  tcvalue_prev = time2asecondary(t + sch_step, pIDX);
883 
884  w_t =
885  tcvalue_now > tcvalue_prev; // w_t = true --> flood , w_t = false --> ebb
886 
887  return true;
888 }
889 
890 void TCMgr::GetHightOrLowTide(time_t t, int sch_step_1, int sch_step_2,
891  float tide_val, bool w_t, int idx, float &tcvalue,
892  time_t &tctime) {
893  // Return a sensible value of 0,0 by default
894  tcvalue = 0;
895  tctime = t;
896 
897  // Load up this location data
898  IDX_entry *pIDX = m_Combined_IDX_array[idx]; // point to the index entry
899 
900  if (!pIDX) return;
901 
902  if (!pIDX->IDX_Useable) return; // no error, but unuseable
903 
904  if (pIDX->pDataSource) {
905  if (pIDX->pDataSource->LoadHarmonicData(pIDX) != TC_NO_ERROR) return;
906  }
907 
908  // Is the cache data reasonably fresh?
909  if (abs(t - pIDX->recent_highlow_calc_time) < 60) {
910  if (w_t) {
911  tcvalue = pIDX->recent_high_level;
912  tctime = pIDX->recent_high_time;
913  } else {
914  tcvalue = pIDX->recent_low_level;
915  tctime = pIDX->recent_low_time;
916  }
917  return;
918  }
919 
920  pIDX->max_amplitude = 0.0; // Force multiplier re-compute
921  int yott = yearoftimet(t);
922  happy_new_year(pIDX, yott);
923 
924  // Finally, calculate the Hight and low tides
925  double newval = tide_val;
926  double oldval = (w_t) ? newval - 1 : newval + 1;
927  int j = 0;
928  int k = 0;
929  int ttt = 0;
930  while ((newval > oldval) == w_t) // searching each ten minute
931  {
932  j++;
933  oldval = newval;
934  ttt = t + (sch_step_1 * j);
935  newval = time2asecondary(ttt, pIDX);
936  }
937  oldval = (w_t) ? newval - 1 : newval + 1;
938  while ((newval > oldval) == w_t) // searching back each minute
939  {
940  oldval = newval;
941  k++;
942  ttt = t + (sch_step_1 * j) - (sch_step_2 * k);
943  newval = time2asecondary(ttt, pIDX);
944  }
945  tcvalue = newval;
946  tctime = ttt + sch_step_2;
947 
948  // Cache the data
949  pIDX->recent_highlow_calc_time = t;
950  if (w_t) {
951  pIDX->recent_high_level = newval;
952  pIDX->recent_high_time = tctime;
953  } else {
954  pIDX->recent_low_level = newval;
955  pIDX->recent_low_time = tctime;
956  }
957 }

959 int TCMgr::GetStationTimeOffset(IDX_entry *pIDX) { return pIDX->IDX_time_zone; }

961 double TCMgr::GetStationLat(IDX_entry *pIDX) { return pIDX->IDX_lat; }

965 int TCMgr::GetNextBigEvent(time_t *tm, int idx) {
966  float tcvalue[1];
967  float dir;
968  bool ret;
969  double p, q;
970  int flags = 0, slope = 0;
971  ret = GetTideOrCurrent(*tm, idx, tcvalue[0], dir);
972  p = tcvalue[0];
973  *tm += 60;
974  ret = GetTideOrCurrent(*tm, idx, tcvalue[0], dir);
975  q = tcvalue[0];
976  *tm += 60;
977  if (p < q) slope = 1;
978  while (1) {
979  if ((slope == 1 && q < p) || (slope == 0 && p < q)) {
980  /* Tide event */
981  flags |= (1 << slope);
982  }
983  if (flags) {
984  *tm -= 60;
985  if (flags < 4) *tm -= 60;
986  return flags;
987  }
988  p = q;
989  ret = GetTideOrCurrent(*tm, idx, tcvalue[0], dir);
990  if (!ret) return 0; // Harmonics file error, data not available
991  q = tcvalue[0];
992  *tm += 60;
993  }
994  return 0;
995 }

997 std::map<double, const IDX_entry *> TCMgr::GetStationsForLL(double xlat,
998  double xlon) const {
999  std::map<double, const IDX_entry *> x;
1000  const IDX_entry *lpIDX;
1001 
1002  for (int j = 1; j < Get_max_IDX() + 1; j++) {
1003  lpIDX = GetIDX_entry(j);
1004  char type = lpIDX->IDX_type;
1005  wxString locnx(lpIDX->IDX_station_name, wxConvUTF8);
1006 
1007  if (type == 't' || type == 'T') {
1008  double brg, dist;
1009  DistanceBearingMercator(xlat, xlon, lpIDX->IDX_lat, lpIDX->IDX_lon, &brg,
1010  &dist);
1011  x.emplace(std::make_pair(dist, lpIDX));
1012  }
1013  }
1014 
1015  return x;
1016 }

1018 int TCMgr::GetStationIDXbyName(const wxString &prefix, double xlat,
1019  double xlon) const {
1020  const IDX_entry *lpIDX;
1021  int jx = 0;
1022  wxString locn;
1023  double distx = 100000.;
1024 
1025  int jmax = Get_max_IDX();
1026 
1027  for (int j = 1; j < Get_max_IDX() + 1; j++) {
1028  lpIDX = GetIDX_entry(j);
1029  char type = lpIDX->IDX_type; // Entry "TCtcIUu" identifier
1030  wxString locnx(lpIDX->IDX_station_name, wxConvUTF8);
1031 
1032  if (((type == 't') || (type == 'T')) // only Tides
1033  && (locnx.StartsWith(prefix))) {
1034  double brg, dist;
1035  DistanceBearingMercator(xlat, xlon, lpIDX->IDX_lat, lpIDX->IDX_lon, &brg,
1036  &dist);
1037  if (dist < distx) {
1038  distx = dist;
1039  jx = j;
1040  }
1041  }
1042  } // end for loop
1043  //} // end if @~~ found in WP
1044  return (jx);
1045 }

1941 
1942  DISTRIBUTION STATEMENT

1951 /* Some of the following commentary is out of date. See the new
1952  documentation in libtcd.html. */
1953 
1954 /****************************************************************************
1955 
1956  Tide Constituent Database API
1957 
1958 
1959  Author : Jan C. Depner (depnerj@navo.navy.mil)
1960 
1961  Date : 08/01/02
1962  (First day of Micro$oft's "Licensing 6" policy - P.T. Barnum was
1963  right!!!)
1964 
1965  Purpose : To replace the ASCII/XML formatted harmonic constituent data
1966  files, used in Dave Flater's (http://www.flaterco.com/xtide/)
1967  exceptionally fine open-source XTide program, with a fast,
1968  efficient binary format. In addition, we wanted to replace the
1969  Naval Oceanographic Office's (http://www.navo.navy.mil)
1970  antiquated ASCII format harmonic constituent data file due to
1971  problems with configuration management of the file. The
1972  resulting database will become a Navy OAML (Oceanographic and
1973  Atmospheric Master Library) standard harmonic tide constituent
1974  database.
1975 
1976  Design : The following describes the database file and some of the
1977  rationale behind the design.
1978 
1979  First question - Why didn't I use PostgreSQL or MySQL? Mostly
1980  portability. What? PostgreSQL runs on everything! Yes, but it doesn't
1981  come installed on everything. This would have meant that the poor,
1982  benighted Micro$oft borgs would have had to actually load a software
1983  package. In addition, the present harmonics/offset files only contain
1984  a total of 6,409 stations. It hardly seemed worth the effort (or overhead)
1985  of a fullblown RDBMS to handle this. Second question - Why binary and not
1986  ASCII or XML? This actually gets into philosophy. At NAVO we have used an
1987  ASCII harmonic constituent file for years (we were founded in 1830 and I
1988  think that that's when they designed the file). We have about fifty
1989  million copies floating around and each one is slightly different. Why?
1990  Because they're ASCII and everyone thinks they know what they're doing so
1991  they tend to modify the file. Same problem with XML, it's still ASCII.
1992  We wanted a file that people weren't going to mess with and that we could
1993  version control. We also wanted a file that was small and fast. This is
1994  very difficult to do with ASCII. The big slowdown with the old format
1995  was I/O and parsing. Third question - will it run on any OS? Hopefully,
1996  yes. After twenty-five years of working with low bidder systems I've
1997  worked on almost every OS known to man. Once you've been bitten by big
1998  endian vs little endian or IEEE floating point format vs VAX floating
1999  point format or byte addressable memory vs word addressable memory or 32
2000  bit word vs 36 bit word vs 48 bit word vs 64 bit word sizes you get the
2001  message. All of the data in the file is stored either as ASCII text or
2002  scaled integers (32 bits or smaller), bit-packed and stuffed into an
2003  unsigned character buffer for I/O. No endian issues, no floating point
2004  issues, no word size issues, no memory mapping issues. I will be testing
2005  this on x86 Linux, HP-UX, and Micro$oft Windoze. By the time you read
2006  this it will be portable to those systems at least.
2007 
2008  Now, on to the file layout. As much as I dislike ASCII it is occasionally
2009  handy to be able to see some information about a file without having to
2010  resort to a special purpose program. With that in mind I made the first
2011  part of the header of the file ASCII. The following is an example of the
2012  ASCII portion of the header:
2013 
2014  [VERSION] = PFM Software - tide_db V1.00 - 08/01/02
2015  [LAST MODIFIED] = Thu Aug 1 02:46:29 2002
2016  [HEADER SIZE] = 4096
2017  [NUMBER OF RECORDS] = 10652
2018  [START YEAR] = 1970
2019  [NUMBER OF YEARS] = 68
2020  [SPEED BITS] = 31
2021  [SPEED SCALE] = 10000000
2022  [SPEED OFFSET] = -410667
2023  [EQUILIBRIUM BITS] = 16
2024  [EQUILIBRIUM SCALE] = 100
2025  [EQUILIBRIUM OFFSET] = 0
2026  [NODE BITS] = 15
2027  [NODE SCALE] = 10000
2028  [NODE OFFSET] = -3949
2029  [AMPLITUDE BITS] = 19
2030  [AMPLITUDE SCALE] = 10000
2031  [EPOCH BITS] = 16
2032  [EPOCH SCALE] = 100
2033  [RECORD TYPE BITS] = 4
2034  [LATITUDE BITS] = 25
2035  [LATITUDE SCALE] = 100000
2036  [LONGITUDE BITS] = 26
2037  [LONGITUDE SCALE] = 100000
2038  [RECORD SIZE BITS] = 12
2039  [STATION BITS] = 18
2040  [DATUM OFFSET BITS] = 32
2041  [DATUM OFFSET SCALE] = 10000
2042  [DATE BITS] = 27
2043  [MONTHS ON STATION BITS] = 10
2044  [CONFIDENCE VALUE BITS] = 4
2045  [TIME BITS] = 13
2046  [LEVEL ADD BITS] = 16
2047  [LEVEL ADD SCALE] = 100
2048  [LEVEL MULTIPLY BITS] = 16
2049  [LEVEL MULTIPLY SCALE] = 1000
2050  [DIRECTION BITS] = 9
2051  [LEVEL UNIT BITS] = 3
2052  [LEVEL UNIT TYPES] = 6
2053  [LEVEL UNIT SIZE] = 15
2054  [DIRECTION UNIT BITS] = 2
2055  [DIRECTION UNIT TYPES] = 3
2056  [DIRECTION UNIT SIZE] = 15
2057  [RESTRICTION BITS] = 4
2058  [RESTRICTION TYPES] = 2
2059  [RESTRICTION SIZE] = 30
2060  [PEDIGREE BITS] = 6
2061  [PEDIGREE TYPES] = 13
2062  [PEDIGREE SIZE] = 60
2063  [DATUM BITS] = 7
2064  [DATUM TYPES] = 61
2065  [DATUM SIZE] = 70
2066  [CONSTITUENT BITS] = 8
2067  [CONSTITUENTS] = 173
2068  [CONSTITUENT SIZE] = 10
2069  [COUNTRY BITS] = 9
2070  [COUNTRIES] = 240
2071  [COUNTRY SIZE] = 50
2072  [TZFILE BITS] = 10
2073  [TZFILES] = 449
2074  [TZFILE SIZE] = 30
2075  [END OF FILE] = 2585170
2076  [END OF ASCII HEADER DATA]
2077 
2078  Most of these values will make sense in the context of the following
2079  description of the rest of the file. Some caveats on the data storage -
2080  if no SCALE is listed for a field, the scale is 1. If no BITS field is
2081  listed, this is a variable length character field and is stored as 8 bit
2082  ASCII characters. If no OFFSET is listed, the offset is 0. Offsets are
2083  scaled. All SIZE fields refer to the maximum length, in characters, of a
2084  variable length character field. Some of the BITS fields are calculated
2085  while others are hardwired (see code). For instance, [DIRECTION BITS] is
2086  hardwired because it is an integer field whose value can only be from 0 to
2087  361 (361 = no direction flag). [NODE BITS], on the other hand, is
2088  calculated on creation by checking the min, max, and range of all of the
2089  node factor values. The number of bits needed is easily calculated by
2090  taking the log of the adjusted, scaled range, dividing by the log of 2 and
2091  adding 1. Immediately following the ASCII portion of the header is a 32
2092  bit checksum of the ASCII portion of the header. Why? Because some
2093  genius always gets the idea that he/she can modify the header with a text
2094  or hex editor. Go figure.
2095 
2096  The rest of the header is as follows :
2097 
2098  [LEVEL UNIT TYPES] fields of [LEVEL UNIT SIZE] characters, each field
2099  is internally 0 terminated (anything after the zero is garbage)
2100 
2101  [DIRECTION UNIT TYPES] fields of [DIRECTION UNIT SIZE] characters, 0
2102  terminated
2103 
2104  [RESTRICTION TYPES] fields of [RESTRICTION SIZE] characters, 0
2105  terminated
2106 
2107  [PEDIGREE TYPES] fields of [PEDIGREE SIZE] characters, 0 terminated
2108 
2109  [TZFILES] fields of [TZFILE SIZE] characters, 0 terminated
2110 
2111  [COUNTRIES] fields of [COUNTRY SIZE] characters, 0 terminated
2112 
2113  [DATUM TYPES] fields of [DATUM SIZE] characters, 0 terminated
2114 
2115  [CONSTITUENTS] fields of [CONSTITUENT SIZE] characters, 0 terminated
2116  Yes, I know, I wasted some space with these fields but I wasn't
2117  worried about a couple of hundred bytes.
2118 
2119  [CONSTITUENTS] fields of [SPEED BITS], speed values (scaled and offset)
2120 
2121  [CONSTITUENTS] groups of [NUMBER OF YEARS] fields of
2122  [EQUILIBRIUM BITS], equilibrium arguments (scaled and offset)
2123 
2124  [CONSTITUENTS] groups of [NUMBER OF YEARS] fields of [NODE BITS], node
2125  factors (scaled and offset)
2126 
2127 
2128  Finally, the data. At present there are two types of records in the file.
2129  These are reference stations (record type 1) and subordinate stations
2130  (record type 2). Reference stations contain a set of constituents while
2131  subordinate stations contain a number of offsets to be applied to the
2132  reference station that they are associated with. Note that reference
2133  stations (record type 1) may, in actuality, be subordinate stations, albeit
2134  with a set of constituents. All of the records have the following subset
2135  of information stored as the first part of the record:
2136 
2137  [RECORD SIZE BITS] - record size in bytes
2138  [RECORD TYPE BITS] - record type (1 or 2)
2139  [LATITUDE BITS] - latitude (degrees, south negative, scaled & offset)
2140  [LONGITUDE BITS] - longitude (degrees, west negative, scaled & offset)
2141  [TZFILE BITS] - index into timezone array (retrieved from header)
2142  variable size - station name, 0 terminated
2143  [STATION BITS] - record number of reference station or -1
2144  [COUNTRY_BITS] index into country array (retrieved from header)
2145  [PEDIGREE BITS] - index into pedigree array (retrieved from header)
2146  variable size - source, 0 terminated
2147  [RESTRICTION BITS] - index into restriction array
2148  variable size - comments, may contain LFs to indicate newline (no CRs)
2149 
2150 
2151  These are the rest of the fields for record type 1:
2152 
2153  [LEVEL UNIT BITS] - index into level units array
2154  [DATUM OFFSET BITS] - datum offset (scaled)
2155  [DATUM BITS] - index into datum name array
2156  [TIME BITS] - time zone offset from GMT0 (meridian, integer +/-HHMM)
2157  [DATE BITS] - expiration date, (integer YYYYMMDD, default is 0)
2158  [MONTHS ON STATION BITS] - months on station
2159  [DATE BITS] - last date on station, default is 0
2160  [CONFIDENCE BITS] - confidence value (TBD)
2161  [CONSTITUENT BITS] - "N", number of constituents for this station
2162 
2163  N groups of:
2164  [CONSTITUENT BITS] - constituent number
2165  [AMPLITUDE BITS] - amplitude (scaled & offset)
2166  [EPOCH BITS] - epoch (scaled & offset)
2167 
2168 
2169  These are the rest of the fields for record type 2:
2170 
2171  [LEVEL UNIT BITS] - leveladd units, index into level_units array
2172  [DIRECTION UNIT BITS] - direction units, index into dir_units array
2173  [LEVEL UNIT BITS] - avglevel units, index into level_units array
2174  [TIME BITS] - min timeadd (integer +/-HHMM) or 0
2175  [LEVEL ADD BITS] - min leveladd (scaled) or 0
2176  [LEVEL MULTIPLY BITS] - min levelmultiply (scaled) or 0
2177  [LEVEL ADD BITS] - min avglevel (scaled) or 0
2178  [DIRECTION BITS] - min direction (0-360 or 361 for no direction)
2179  [TIME BITS] - max timeadd (integer +/-HHMM) or 0
2180  [LEVEL ADD BITS] - max leveladd (scaled) or 0
2181  [LEVEL MULTIPLY BITS] - max levelmultiply (scaled) or 0
2182  [LEVEL ADD BITS] - max avglevel (scaled) or 0
2183  [DIRECTION BITS] - max direction (0-360 or 361 for no direction)
2184  [TIME BITS] - floodbegins (integer +/-HHMM) or NULLSLACKOFFSET
2185  [TIME BITS] - ebbbegins (integer +/-HHMM) or NULLSLACKOFFSET
2186 
2187 
2188  Back to philosophy! When you design a database of any kind the first
2189  thing you should ask yourself is "Self, how am I going to access this
2190  data most of the time?". If you answer yourself out loud you should
2191  consider seeing a shrink. 99 and 44/100ths percent of the time this
2192  database is going to be read to get station data. The other 66/100ths
2193  percent of the time it will be created/modified. Variable length records
2194  are no problem on retrieval. They are no problem to create. They can be
2195  a major pain in the backside if you have to modify/delete them. Since we
2196  shouldn't be doing too much editing of the data (usually just adding
2197  records) this is a pretty fair design. At some point though we are going
2198  to want to modify or delete a record. There are two possibilities here.
2199  We can dump the database to an ASCII file or files using restore_tide_db,
2200  use a text editor to modify them, and then rebuild the database. The
2201  other possibility is to modify the record in place. This is OK if you
2202  don't change a variable length field but what if you want to change the
2203  station name or add a couple of constituents? With the design as is we
2204  have to read the remainder of the file from the end of the record to be
2205  modified, write the modified record, rewrite the remainder of the file,
2206  and then change the end_of_file pointer in the header. So, which fields
2207  are going to be a problem? Changes to station name, source, comments, or
2208  the number of constituents for a station will require a resizing of the
2209  database. Changes to any of the other fields can be done in place. The
2210  worst thing that you can do though is to delete a record. Not just
2211  because the file has to be resized but because it might be a reference
2212  record with subordinate stations. These would have to be deleted as well.
2213  The delete_tide_record function will do just that so make sure you check
2214  before you call it. You might not want to do that.
2215 
2216  Another point to note is that when you open the database the records are
2217  indexed at that point. This takes about half a second on a dual 450.
2218  Most applications use the header part of the record very often and
2219  the rest of the record only if they are going to actually produce
2220  predicted tides. For instance, XTide plots all of the stations on a
2221  world map or globe and lists all of the station names. It also needs the
2222  timezone up front. To save re-indexing to get these values I save them
2223  in memory. The only time an application needs to actually read an entire
2224  record is when you want to do the prediction. Otherwise just use
2225  get_partial_tide_record or get_next_partial_tide_record to yank the good
2226  stuff out of memory.
2227 
2228  'Nuff said?
2229 
2230 
2231  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2232 
2233 *****************************************************************************/
2234

2241 NV_U_INT32 bit_unpack(NV_U_BYTE *, NV_U_INT32, NV_U_INT32);
2242 NV_INT32 signed_bit_unpack(NV_U_BYTE buffer[], NV_U_INT32 start,
2243  NV_U_INT32 numbits);

2264 /*****************************************************************************\
2265  Checked fread and fwrite wrappers
2266  DWF 2007-12-02
2267 
2268  Fedora package compiles generate warnings for invoking these
2269  functions without checking the return.
2270 \*****************************************************************************/
2271 
2272 static void chk_fread(void *ptr, size_t size, size_t nmemb, FILE *stream) {
2273  size_t ret;
2274  ret = fread(ptr, size, nmemb, stream);
2275  if (ret != nmemb) {
2276  // LOG_ERROR ("libtcd unexpected error: fread failed\n");
2277  // LOG_ERROR ("nmemb = %lu, got %lu\n", nmemb, ret);
2278  abort();
2279  }
2280 }
2281 
2282 static void chk_fwrite(const void *ptr, size_t size, size_t nmemb,
2283  FILE *stream) {
2284  size_t ret;
2285  ret = fwrite(ptr, size, nmemb, stream);
2286  if (ret != nmemb) {
2287  // LOG_ERROR ("libtcd unexpected error: fwrite failed\n");
2288  // LOG_ERROR ("nmemb = %lu, got %lu\n", nmemb, ret);
2289  // LOG_ERROR ("The database is probably corrupt now.\n");
2290  abort();
2291  }
2292 }

2294 /*****************************************************************************\
2295 
2296  Function dump_tide_record - prints out all of the fields in the
2297  input tide record
2298 
2299  Synopsis dump_tide_record (rec);
2300 
2301  TIDE_RECORD *rec pointer to the tide record
2302 
2303  Returns void
2304 
2305  Author Jan C. Depner
2306  Date 08/01/02
2307 
2308  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2309 
2310 \*****************************************************************************/
2311 
2312 void dump_tide_record(const TIDE_RECORD *rec) {
2313  NV_U_INT32 i;
2314 
2315  assert(rec);
2316 
2317  LOG_ERROR("\n\nRecord number = %d\n", rec->header.record_number);
2318  LOG_ERROR("Record size = %u\n", rec->header.record_size);
2319  LOG_ERROR("Record type = %u\n", rec->header.record_type);
2320  LOG_ERROR("Latitude = %f\n", rec->header.latitude);
2321  LOG_ERROR("Longitude = %f\n", rec->header.longitude);
2322  LOG_ERROR("Reference station = %d\n", rec->header.reference_station);
2323  LOG_ERROR("Tzfile = %s\n", get_tzfile(rec->header.tzfile));
2324  LOG_ERROR("Name = %s\n", rec->header.name);
2325 
2326  LOG_ERROR("Country = %s\n", get_country(rec->country));
2327  LOG_ERROR("Source = %s\n", rec->source);
2328  LOG_ERROR("Restriction = %s\n", get_restriction(rec->restriction));
2329  LOG_ERROR("Comments = %s\n", rec->comments);
2330  LOG_ERROR("Notes = %s\n", rec->notes);
2331  LOG_ERROR("Legalese = %s\n", get_legalese(rec->legalese));
2332  LOG_ERROR("Station ID context = %s\n", rec->station_id_context);
2333  LOG_ERROR("Station ID = %s\n", rec->station_id);
2334  LOG_ERROR("Date imported = %d\n", rec->date_imported);
2335  LOG_ERROR("Xfields = %s\n", rec->xfields);
2336 
2337  LOG_ERROR("Direction units = %s\n", get_dir_units(rec->direction_units));
2338  LOG_ERROR("Min direction = %d\n", rec->min_direction);
2339  LOG_ERROR("Max direction = %d\n", rec->max_direction);
2340  LOG_ERROR("Level units = %s\n", get_level_units(rec->level_units));
2341 
2342  if (rec->header.record_type == REFERENCE_STATION) {
2343  LOG_ERROR("Datum offset = %f\n", rec->datum_offset);
2344  LOG_ERROR("Datum = %s\n", get_datum(rec->datum));
2345  LOG_ERROR("Zone offset = %d\n", rec->zone_offset);
2346  LOG_ERROR("Expiration date = %d\n", rec->expiration_date);
2347  LOG_ERROR("Months on station = %d\n", rec->months_on_station);
2348  LOG_ERROR("Last date on station = %d\n", rec->last_date_on_station);
2349  LOG_ERROR("Confidence = %d\n", rec->confidence);
2350  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.constituents; ++i) {
2351  if (rec->amplitude[i] != 0.0 || rec->epoch[i] != 0.0) {
2352  LOG_ERROR("Amplitude[%d] = %f\n", i, rec->amplitude[i]);
2353  LOG_ERROR("Epoch[%d] = %f\n", i, rec->epoch[i]);
2354  }
2355  }
2356  }
2357 
2358  else if (rec->header.record_type == SUBORDINATE_STATION) {
2359  LOG_ERROR("Min time add = %d\n", rec->min_time_add);
2360  LOG_ERROR("Min level add = %f\n", rec->min_level_add);
2361  LOG_ERROR("Min level multiply = %f\n", rec->min_level_multiply);
2362  LOG_ERROR("Max time add = %d\n", rec->max_time_add);
2363  LOG_ERROR("Max level add = %f\n", rec->max_level_add);
2364  LOG_ERROR("Max level multiply = %f\n", rec->max_level_multiply);
2365  LOG_ERROR("Flood begins = %d\n", rec->flood_begins);
2366  LOG_ERROR("Ebb begins = %d\n", rec->ebb_begins);
2367  }
2368 }

2370 /*****************************************************************************\
2371 
2372  Function write_protect - prevent trying to modify TCD files of
2373  an earlier version. Nothing to do with file locking.
2374 
2375  David Flater, 2004-10-14.
2376 
2377 \*****************************************************************************/
2378 
2379 static void write_protect() {
2380  if (hd.pub.major_rev < LIBTCD_MAJOR_REV) {
2381  LOG_ERROR(
2382  "libtcd error: can't modify TCD files created by earlier version. "
2383  "Use\nrewrite_tide_db to upgrade the TCD file.\n");
2384  exit(-1);
2385  }
2386 }

2388 /*****************************************************************************\
2389 
2390  Function get_country - gets the country field for record "num"
2391 
2392  Synopsis get_country (num);
2393 
2394  NV_INT32 num tide record number
2395 
2396  Returns NV_CHAR * country name (associated with
2397  ISO 3166-1:1999 2-character
2398  country code
2399 
2400  Author Jan C. Depner
2401  Date 08/01/02
2402 
2403  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2404 
2405 \*****************************************************************************/
2406 
2407 const NV_CHAR *get_country(NV_INT32 num) {
2408  if (!fp) {
2409  LOG_ERROR(
2410  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
2411  exit(-1);
2412  }
2413  if (num >= 0 && num < (NV_INT32)hd.pub.countries) return (hd.country[num]);
2414  return ("Unknown");
2415 }

2764 /*****************************************************************************\
2765 
2766  Function get_partial_tide_record - gets "header" portion of record
2767  "num" from the index that is stored in memory. This is
2768  way faster than reading it again and we have to read it
2769  to set up the index. This costs a bit in terms of
2770  memory but most applications use this data far more than
2771  the rest of the record.
2772 
2773  Synopsis get_partial_tide_record (num, rec);
2774 
2775  NV_INT32 num record number
2776  TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec header portion of the record
2777 
2778  Returns NV_BOOL NVTrue if successful
2779 
2780  Author Jan C. Depner
2781  Date 08/01/02
2782 
2783  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2784 
2785 \*****************************************************************************/
2786 
2787 NV_BOOL get_partial_tide_record(NV_INT32 num, TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec) {
2788  if (!fp) {
2789  LOG_ERROR(
2790  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
2791  return NVFalse;
2792  }
2793 
2794  if (num < 0 || num >= (NV_INT32)hd.pub.number_of_records) return (NVFalse);
2795 
2796  assert(rec);
2797 
2798  rec->record_number = num;
2799  rec->record_size = tindex[num].record_size;
2800  rec->record_type = tindex[num].record_type;
2801  rec->latitude = (NV_FLOAT64)tindex[num].lat / hd.latitude_scale;
2802  rec->longitude = (NV_FLOAT64)tindex[num].lon / hd.longitude_scale;
2803  rec->reference_station = tindex[num].reference_station;
2804  rec->tzfile = tindex[num].tzfile;
2805  strcpy(rec->name, tindex[num].name);
2806 
2807  current_index = num;
2808 
2809  return (NVTrue);
2810 }
2811 
2812 /*****************************************************************************\
2813 
2814  Function get_next_partial_tide_record - gets "header" portion of
2815  the next record from the index that is stored in memory.
2816 
2817  Synopsis get_next_partial_tide_record (rec);
2818 
2819  TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec header portion of the record
2820 
2821  Returns NV_INT32 record number or -1 on failure
2822 
2823  Author Jan C. Depner
2824  Date 08/01/02
2825 
2826  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2827 
2828 \*****************************************************************************/
2829 
2830 NV_INT32 get_next_partial_tide_record(TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec) {
2831  if (!get_partial_tide_record(current_index + 1, rec)) return (-1);
2832 
2833  return (current_index);
2834 }
2835 
2836 /*****************************************************************************\
2837 
2838  Function get_nearest_partial_tide_record - gets "header" portion of
2839  the record closest geographically to the input position.
2840 
2841  Synopsis get_nearest_partial_tide_record (lat, lon, rec);
2842 
2843  NV_FLOAT64 lat latitude
2844  NV_FLOAT64 lon longitude
2845  TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec header portion of the record
2846 
2847  Returns NV_INT32 record number or -1 on failure
2848 
2849  Author Jan C. Depner
2850  Date 08/01/02
2851 
2852  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2853 
2854 \*****************************************************************************/
2855 
2856 NV_INT32 get_nearest_partial_tide_record(NV_FLOAT64 lat, NV_FLOAT64 lon,
2857  TIDE_STATION_HEADER *rec) {
2858  NV_FLOAT64 diff, min_diff, lt, ln;
2859  NV_U_INT32 i, shortest = 0;
2860 
2861  min_diff = 999999999.9;
2862  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.number_of_records; ++i) {
2863  lt = (NV_FLOAT64)tindex[i].lat / hd.latitude_scale;
2864  ln = (NV_FLOAT64)tindex[i].lon / hd.longitude_scale;
2865 
2866  diff = sqrt((lat - lt) * (lat - lt) + (lon - ln) * (lon - ln));
2867 
2868  if (diff < min_diff) {
2869  min_diff = diff;
2870  shortest = i;
2871  }
2872  }
2873 
2874  if (!get_partial_tide_record(shortest, rec)) return (-1);
2875  return (shortest);
2876 }

2878 /*****************************************************************************\
2879 
2880  Function get_time - converts a time string in +/-HH:MM form to an
2881  integer in +/-HHMM form
2882 
2883  Synopsis get_time (string);
2884 
2885  NV_CHAR *string time string
2886 
2887  Returns NV_INT32 time
2888 
2889  Author Jan C. Depner
2890  Date 08/01/02
2891 
2892  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2893 
2894 \*****************************************************************************/
2895 
2896 NV_INT32 get_time(const NV_CHAR *string) {
2897  NV_INT32 hour, minute, hhmm;
2898 
2899  assert(string);
2900  sscanf(string, "%d:%d", &hour, &minute);
2901 
2902  /* Trying to deal with negative 0 (-00:45). */
2903 
2904  if (string[0] == '-') {
2905  if (hour < 0) hour = -hour;
2906 
2907  hhmm = -(hour * 100 + minute);
2908  } else {
2909  hhmm = hour * 100 + minute;
2910  }
2911 
2912  return (hhmm);
2913 }
2914 
2915 /*****************************************************************************\
2916 
2917  Function ret_time - converts a time value in +/-HHMM form to a
2918  time string in +/-HH:MM form
2919 
2920  Synopsis ret_time (time);
2921 
2922  NV_INT32 time
2923 
2924  Returns NV_CHAR * time string
2925 
2926  Author Jan C. Depner
2927  Date 08/01/02
2928 
2929  See libtcd.html for changelog.
2930 
2931 \*****************************************************************************/
2932 
2933 NV_CHAR *ret_time(NV_INT32 time) {
2934  NV_INT32 hour, minute;
2935  static NV_CHAR tname[16];
2936 
2937  hour = abs(time) / 100;
2938  assert(hour <= 99999 && hour >= -99999); /* 9 chars: +99999:99 */
2939  minute = abs(time) % 100;
2940 
2941  if (time < 0) {
2942  sprintf(tname, "-%02d:%02d", hour, minute);
2943  } else {
2944  sprintf(tname, "+%02d:%02d", hour, minute);
2945  }
2946 
2947  return tname;
2948 }
2949 
2950 /*****************************************************************************\
2951  DWF 2004-10-04
2952 \*****************************************************************************/
2953 NV_CHAR *ret_time_neat(NV_INT32 time) {
2954  NV_INT32 hour, minute;
2955  static NV_CHAR tname[16];
2956 
2957  hour = abs(time) / 100;
2958  assert(hour <= 99999 && hour >= -99999); /* 9 chars: +99999:99 */
2959  minute = abs(time) % 100;
2960 
2961  if (time < 0)
2962  sprintf(tname, "-%d:%02d", hour, minute);
2963  else if (time > 0)
2964  sprintf(tname, "+%d:%02d", hour, minute);
2965  else
2966  strcpy(tname, "0:00");
2967 
2968  return tname;
2969 }
2970 
2971 /*****************************************************************************\
2972  DWF 2004-10-04
2973 \*****************************************************************************/
2974 NV_CHAR *ret_date(NV_U_INT32 date) {
2975  static NV_CHAR tname[30];
2976  if (!date)
2977  strcpy(tname, "NULL");
2978  else {
2979  unsigned y, m, d;
2980  y = date / 10000;
2981  date %= 10000;
2982  m = date / 100;
2983  d = date % 100;
2984  sprintf(tname, "%4u-%02u-%02u", y, m, d);
2985  }
2986  return tname;
2987 }

3014 /*****************************************************************************\
3015  DWF 2004-09-30
3016  Prevent buffer overflows for MONOLOGUE_LENGTH strings.
3017 \*****************************************************************************/
3018 static void boundscheck_monologue(const NV_CHAR *string) {
3019  assert(string);
3020  if (strlen(string) >= MONOLOGUE_LENGTH) {
3021  // LOG_ERROR ("libtcd fatal error: static buffer size exceeded\n");
3022  // LOG_ERROR ("Buffer is size MONOLOGUE_LENGTH (%u)\n",
3023  // MONOLOGUE_LENGTH);
3024  // LOG_ERROR ("String is length %lu\n", strlen(string));
3025  // LOG_ERROR ("The offending string is:\n%s\n", string);
3026  exit(-1);
3027  }
3028 }
3029 
3030 /*****************************************************************************\
3031  DWF 2004-09-30
3032  Prevent buffer overflows for ONELINER_LENGTH strings.
3033 \*****************************************************************************/
3034 static void boundscheck_oneliner(const NV_CHAR *string) {
3035  assert(string);
3036  if (strlen(string) >= ONELINER_LENGTH) {
3037  // LOG_ERROR ("libtcd fatal error: static buffer size exceeded\n");
3038  // LOG_ERROR ("Buffer is size ONELINER_LENGTH (%u)\n",
3039  // ONELINER_LENGTH);
3040  // LOG_ERROR ("String is length %lu\n", strlen(string));
3041  // LOG_ERROR ("The offending string is:\n%s\n", string);
3042  exit(-1);
3043  }
3044 }
3045 
3046 /*****************************************************************************\
3047 
3048  Function clip_string - removes leading and trailing spaces from
3049  search strings.
3050 
3051  Synopsis clip_string (string);
3052 
3053  NV_CHAR *string search string
3054 
3055  Returns NV_CHAR * clipped string
3056 
3057  Author Jan C. Depner
3058  Date 09/16/02
3059 
3060  See libtcd.html for changelog.
3061 
3062 \*****************************************************************************/
3063 
3064 static NV_CHAR *clip_string(const NV_CHAR *string) {
3065  static NV_CHAR new_string[MONOLOGUE_LENGTH];
3066  NV_INT32 i, l, start = -1, end = -1;
3067 
3068  boundscheck_monologue(string);
3069  new_string[0] = '\0';
3070 
3071  l = (int)strlen(string);
3072  if (l) {
3073  for (i = 0; i < l; ++i) {
3074  if (string[i] != ' ') {
3075  start = i;
3076  break;
3077  }
3078  }
3079  for (i = l - 1; i >= start; --i) {
3080  if (string[i] != ' ' && string[i] != 10 && string[i] != 13) {
3081  end = i;
3082  break;
3083  }
3084  }
3085  if (start > -1 && end > -1 && end >= start) {
3086  strncpy(new_string, string + start, end - start + 1);
3087  new_string[end - start + 1] = '\0';
3088  }
3089  }
3090  return new_string;
3091 }
3092 
3093 /*****************************************************************************\
3094 
3095  Function search_station - returns record numbers of all stations
3096  that have the string "string" anywhere in the station
3097  name. This search is case insensitive. When no more
3098  records are found it returns -1;
3099 
3100  Synopsis search_station (string);
3101 
3102  NV_CHAR *string search string
3103 
3104  Returns NV_INT32 record number or -1 when no more
3105  matches
3106 
3107  Author Jan C. Depner
3108  Date 08/01/02
3109 
3110  See libtcd.html for changelog.
3111 
3112 \*****************************************************************************/
3113 
3114 NV_INT32 search_station(const NV_CHAR *string) {
3115  static NV_CHAR last_search[ONELINER_LENGTH];
3116  static NV_U_INT32 j = 0;
3117  NV_U_INT32 i;
3118  NV_CHAR name[ONELINER_LENGTH], search[ONELINER_LENGTH];
3119 
3120  if (!fp) {
3121  LOG_ERROR(
3122  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
3123  return -1;
3124  }
3125 
3126  boundscheck_oneliner(string);
3127 
3128  for (i = 0; i < strlen(string) + 1; ++i) search[i] = tolower(string[i]);
3129 
3130  if (strcmp(search, last_search)) j = 0;
3131 
3132  strcpy(last_search, search);
3133 
3134  while (j < hd.pub.number_of_records) {
3135  for (i = 0; i < strlen(tindex[j].name) + 1; ++i)
3136  name[i] = tolower(tindex[j].name[i]);
3137 
3138  ++j;
3139  if (strstr(name, search)) return (j - 1);
3140  }
3141 
3142  j = 0;
3143  return -1;
3144 }

3146 /*****************************************************************************\

3163 
3164 NV_INT32 find_station(const NV_CHAR *name) {

3185

3533  See libtcd.html for changelog.

3537 void set_speed(NV_INT32 num, NV_FLOAT64 value) {
3538  if (!fp) {
3539  LOG_ERROR(
3540  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
3541  exit(-1);
3542  }
3543  write_protect();
3544  assert(num >= 0 && num < (NV_INT32)hd.pub.constituents);
3545  if (value < 0.0) {
3546  LOG_ERROR("libtcd set_speed: somebody tried to set a negative speed (%f)\n",
3547  value);
3548  exit(-1);
3549  }
3550  hd.speed[num] = value;
3551  modified = NVTrue;
3552 }

3651 /*****************************************************************************\
3652 
3653  Function add_tzfile - adds a new tzfile to the database
3654 
3655  Synopsis add_tzfile (name, db);
3656 
3657  NV_CHAR *name new tzfile string
3658  DB_HEADER_PUBLIC *db modified header
3659 
3660  Returns NV_INT32 new tzfile index
3661 
3662  Author Jan C. Depner
3663  Date 09/20/02
3664 
3665  See libtcd.html for changelog.
3666 
3667 \*****************************************************************************/
3668 
3669 NV_INT32 add_tzfile(const NV_CHAR *name, DB_HEADER_PUBLIC *db) {
3670  NV_CHAR *c_name;
3671 
3672  if (!fp) {
3673  LOG_ERROR(
3674  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
3675  exit(-1);
3676  }
3677  write_protect();
3678 
3679  assert(name);
3680  if (strlen(name) + 1 > hd.tzfile_size) {
3681  LOG_ERROR("libtcd error: tzfile exceeds size limit (%u).\n",
3682  hd.tzfile_size);
3683  LOG_ERROR("The offending input is: %s\n", name);
3684  exit(-1);
3685  }
3686 
3687  if (hd.pub.tzfiles == hd.max_tzfiles) {
3688  LOG_ERROR("You have exceeded the maximum number of tzfile types!\n");
3689  LOG_ERROR("You cannot add any new tzfile types.\n");
3690  LOG_ERROR("Modify the DEFAULT_TZFILE_BITS and rebuild the database.\n");
3691  exit(-1);
3692  }
3693 
3694  c_name = clip_string(name);
3695 
3696  hd.tzfile[hd.pub.tzfiles] =
3697  (NV_CHAR *)calloc(strlen(c_name) + 1, sizeof(NV_CHAR));
3698 
3699  if (hd.tzfile[hd.pub.tzfiles] == NULL) {
3700  perror("Allocating new tzfile string");
3701  exit(-1);
3702  }
3703 
3704  strcpy(hd.tzfile[hd.pub.tzfiles++], c_name);
3705  if (db) *db = hd.pub;
3706  modified = NVTrue;
3707  return (hd.pub.tzfiles - 1);
3708 }

3931 /*****************************************************************************\
3932  DWF 2004-10-04
3933 \*****************************************************************************/
3934 NV_INT32 find_or_add_restriction(const NV_CHAR *name, DB_HEADER_PUBLIC *db) {
3935  NV_INT32 ret;
3936  ret = find_restriction(name);
3937  if (ret < 0) ret = add_restriction(name, db);
3938  assert(ret >= 0);
3939  return ret;
3940 }

3986 /*****************************************************************************\
3987 
3988  Function check_simple - checks tide record to see if it is a
3989  "simple" subordinate station.
3990 
3991  Synopsis check_simple (rec);
3992 
3993  TIDE_RECORD rec tide record
3994 
3995  Returns NV_BOOL NVTrue if "simple"
3996 
3997  Author Jan C. Depner
3998  Date 08/01/02
3999 
4000  See libtcd.html for changelog.
4001 
4002  "Simplified" type 2 records were done away with 2003-03-27 per the
4003  discussion in http://www.flaterco.com/xtide/tcd_notes.html. This
4004  function is now of interest only in restore_tide_db, which uses it
4005  to determine which XML format to output. Deprecated here, moved
4006  to restore_tide_db.
4007 
4008 \*****************************************************************************/
4009 
4010 #ifdef COMPAT114
4011 NV_BOOL check_simple(TIDE_RECORD rec) {
4012  if (rec.max_time_add == rec.min_time_add &&
4013  rec.max_level_add == rec.min_level_add &&
4014  rec.max_level_multiply == rec.min_level_multiply &&
4015  rec.max_avg_level == 0 && rec.min_avg_level == 0 &&
4016  rec.max_direction == 361 && rec.min_direction == 361 &&
4017  rec.flood_begins == NULLSLACKOFFSET && rec.ebb_begins == NULLSLACKOFFSET)
4018  return (NVTrue);
4019 
4020  return (NVFalse);
4021 }
4022 #endif

4108  checksum = crc_table[(checksum ^ buf[i]) & 0xff] ^ (checksum >> 8);
4109  }
4110  checksum ^= ~0;
4111

4113

4119 /*****************************************************************************\
4120 
4121  Function old_header_checksum - compute the old-style checksum for
4122  the ASCII portion of the database header just in case this
4123  is a pre 1.02 file.
4124 
4125  Synopsis old_header_checksum ();
4126 
4127  Returns NV_U_INT32 checksum value
4128 
4129  Author Jan C. Depner
4130  Date 11/15/02
4131 
4132 \*****************************************************************************/
4133 
4134 #ifdef COMPAT114
4135 static NV_U_INT32 old_header_checksum() {
4136  NV_U_INT32 checksum, i, save_pos;
4137  NV_U_BYTE *buf;
4138 
4139  if (!fp) {
4140  LOG_ERROR(
4141  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
4142  exit(-1);
4143  }
4144 
4145  save_pos = ftell(fp);
4146 
4147  checksum = 0;
4148 
4149  fseek(fp, 0, SEEK_SET);
4150 
4151  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(hd.header_size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4152  perror("Allocating checksum buffer");
4153  exit(-1);
4154  }
4155 
4156  chk_fread(buf, hd.header_size, 1, fp);
4157 
4158  for (i = 0; i < hd.header_size; ++i) checksum += buf[i];
4159 
4160  free(buf);
4161 
4162  fseek(fp, save_pos, SEEK_SET);
4163 
4164  return (checksum);
4165 }
4166 #endif

4168 /*****************************************************************************\
4169  DWF 2004-10-01
4170  Get current time in preferred format.
4171 \*****************************************************************************/
4172 static NV_CHAR *curtime() {
4173  static NV_CHAR buf[ONELINER_LENGTH];
4174  time_t t = time(NULL);
4175  require(strftime(buf, ONELINER_LENGTH, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M %Z", localtime(&t)) >
4176  0);
4177  return buf;
4178 }
4179 
4180 /*****************************************************************************\
4181  DWF 2004-10-15
4182  Calculate bytes for number of bits.
4183 \*****************************************************************************/
4184 static NV_U_INT32 bits2bytes(NV_U_INT32 nbits) {
4185  if (nbits % 8) return nbits / 8 + 1;
4186  return nbits / 8;
4187 }

4189 /*****************************************************************************\
4190 
4191  Function write_tide_db_header - writes the database header to the
4192  file
4193 
4194  Synopsis write_tide_db_header ();
4195 
4196  Returns void
4197 
4198  Author Jan C. Depner
4199  Date 08/01/02
4200 
4201  See libtcd.html for changelog.
4202 
4203 \*****************************************************************************/
4204 
4205 static void write_tide_db_header() {
4206  NV_U_INT32 i, size, pos;
4207  NV_INT32 start, temp_int;
4208  static NV_CHAR zero = 0;
4209  NV_U_BYTE *buf, checksum_c[4];
4210 
4211  if (!fp) {
4212  LOG_ERROR(
4213  "libtcd error: attempt to access database when database not open\n");
4214  exit(-1);
4215  }
4216  write_protect();
4217 
4218  fseek(fp, 0, SEEK_SET);
4219 
4220  fprintf(fp, "[VERSION] = %s\n", LIBTCD_VERSION);
4221  fprintf(fp, "[MAJOR REV] = %u\n", LIBTCD_MAJOR_REV);
4222  fprintf(fp, "[MINOR REV] = %u\n", LIBTCD_MINOR_REV);
4223 
4224  fprintf(fp, "[LAST MODIFIED] = %s\n", curtime());
4225 
4226  fprintf(fp, "[HEADER SIZE] = %u\n", hd.header_size);
4227  fprintf(fp, "[NUMBER OF RECORDS] = %u\n", hd.pub.number_of_records);
4228 
4229  fprintf(fp, "[START YEAR] = %d\n", hd.pub.start_year);
4230  fprintf(fp, "[NUMBER OF YEARS] = %u\n", hd.pub.number_of_years);
4231 
4232  fprintf(fp, "[SPEED BITS] = %u\n", hd.speed_bits);
4233  fprintf(fp, "[SPEED SCALE] = %u\n", hd.speed_scale);
4234  fprintf(fp, "[SPEED OFFSET] = %d\n", hd.speed_offset);
4235  fprintf(fp, "[EQUILIBRIUM BITS] = %u\n", hd.equilibrium_bits);
4236  fprintf(fp, "[EQUILIBRIUM SCALE] = %u\n", hd.equilibrium_scale);
4237  fprintf(fp, "[EQUILIBRIUM OFFSET] = %d\n", hd.equilibrium_offset);
4238  fprintf(fp, "[NODE BITS] = %u\n", hd.node_bits);
4239  fprintf(fp, "[NODE SCALE] = %u\n", hd.node_scale);
4240  fprintf(fp, "[NODE OFFSET] = %d\n", hd.node_offset);
4241  fprintf(fp, "[AMPLITUDE BITS] = %u\n", hd.amplitude_bits);
4242  fprintf(fp, "[AMPLITUDE SCALE] = %u\n", hd.amplitude_scale);
4243  fprintf(fp, "[EPOCH BITS] = %u\n", hd.epoch_bits);
4244  fprintf(fp, "[EPOCH SCALE] = %u\n", hd.epoch_scale);
4245 
4246  fprintf(fp, "[RECORD TYPE BITS] = %u\n", hd.record_type_bits);
4247  fprintf(fp, "[LATITUDE BITS] = %u\n", hd.latitude_bits);
4248  fprintf(fp, "[LATITUDE SCALE] = %u\n", hd.latitude_scale);
4249  fprintf(fp, "[LONGITUDE BITS] = %u\n", hd.longitude_bits);
4250  fprintf(fp, "[LONGITUDE SCALE] = %u\n", hd.longitude_scale);
4251  fprintf(fp, "[RECORD SIZE BITS] = %u\n", hd.record_size_bits);
4252 
4253  fprintf(fp, "[STATION BITS] = %u\n", hd.station_bits);
4254 
4255  fprintf(fp, "[DATUM OFFSET BITS] = %u\n", hd.datum_offset_bits);
4256  fprintf(fp, "[DATUM OFFSET SCALE] = %u\n", hd.datum_offset_scale);
4257  fprintf(fp, "[DATE BITS] = %u\n", hd.date_bits);
4258  fprintf(fp, "[MONTHS ON STATION BITS] = %u\n", hd.months_on_station_bits);
4259  fprintf(fp, "[CONFIDENCE VALUE BITS] = %u\n", hd.confidence_value_bits);
4260 
4261  fprintf(fp, "[TIME BITS] = %u\n", hd.time_bits);
4262  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL ADD BITS] = %u\n", hd.level_add_bits);
4263  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL ADD SCALE] = %u\n", hd.level_add_scale);
4264  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL MULTIPLY BITS] = %u\n", hd.level_multiply_bits);
4265  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL MULTIPLY SCALE] = %u\n", hd.level_multiply_scale);
4266  fprintf(fp, "[DIRECTION BITS] = %u\n", hd.direction_bits);
4267 
4268  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL UNIT BITS] = %u\n", hd.level_unit_bits);
4269  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL UNIT TYPES] = %u\n", hd.pub.level_unit_types);
4270  fprintf(fp, "[LEVEL UNIT SIZE] = %u\n", hd.level_unit_size);
4271 
4272  fprintf(fp, "[DIRECTION UNIT BITS] = %u\n", hd.dir_unit_bits);
4273  fprintf(fp, "[DIRECTION UNIT TYPES] = %u\n", hd.pub.dir_unit_types);
4274  fprintf(fp, "[DIRECTION UNIT SIZE] = %u\n", hd.dir_unit_size);
4275 
4276  fprintf(fp, "[RESTRICTION BITS] = %u\n", hd.restriction_bits);
4277  fprintf(fp, "[RESTRICTION TYPES] = %u\n", hd.pub.restriction_types);
4278  fprintf(fp, "[RESTRICTION SIZE] = %u\n", hd.restriction_size);
4279 
4280  fprintf(fp, "[DATUM BITS] = %u\n", hd.datum_bits);
4281  fprintf(fp, "[DATUM TYPES] = %u\n", hd.pub.datum_types);
4282  fprintf(fp, "[DATUM SIZE] = %u\n", hd.datum_size);
4283 
4284  fprintf(fp, "[LEGALESE BITS] = %u\n", hd.legalese_bits);
4285  fprintf(fp, "[LEGALESE TYPES] = %u\n", hd.pub.legaleses);
4286  fprintf(fp, "[LEGALESE SIZE] = %u\n", hd.legalese_size);
4287 
4288  fprintf(fp, "[CONSTITUENT BITS] = %u\n", hd.constituent_bits);
4289  fprintf(fp, "[CONSTITUENTS] = %u\n", hd.pub.constituents);
4290  fprintf(fp, "[CONSTITUENT SIZE] = %u\n", hd.constituent_size);
4291 
4292  fprintf(fp, "[TZFILE BITS] = %u\n", hd.tzfile_bits);
4293  fprintf(fp, "[TZFILES] = %u\n", hd.pub.tzfiles);
4294  fprintf(fp, "[TZFILE SIZE] = %u\n", hd.tzfile_size);
4295 
4296  fprintf(fp, "[COUNTRY BITS] = %u\n", hd.country_bits);
4297  fprintf(fp, "[COUNTRIES] = %u\n", hd.pub.countries);
4298  fprintf(fp, "[COUNTRY SIZE] = %u\n", hd.country_size);
4299 
4300  fprintf(fp, "[END OF FILE] = %u\n", hd.end_of_file);
4301  fprintf(fp, "[END OF ASCII HEADER DATA]\n");
4302 
4303  /* Fill the remainder of the [HEADER SIZE] ASCII header with zeroes. */
4304 
4305  start = ftell(fp);
4306  assert(start >= 0);
4307  for (i = start; i < hd.header_size; ++i) chk_fwrite(&zero, 1, 1, fp);
4308  fflush(fp);
4309 
4310  /* Compute and save the checksum. */
4311 
4312  bit_pack(checksum_c, 0, 32, header_checksum());
4313  chk_fwrite(checksum_c, 4, 1, fp);
4314 
4315  /* NOTE : Using strcpy for character strings (no endian issue). */
4316 
4317  /* Write level units. */
4318 
4319  pos = 0;
4320  size = hd.pub.level_unit_types * hd.level_unit_size;
4321 
4322  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4323  perror("Allocating unit write buffer");
4324  exit(-1);
4325  }
4326  memset(buf, 0, size);
4327 
4328  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.level_unit_types; ++i) {
4329  assert(strlen(hd.level_unit[i]) + 1 <= hd.level_unit_size);
4330  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.level_unit[i]);
4331  pos += hd.level_unit_size;
4332  }
4333 
4334  chk_fwrite(buf, pos, 1, fp);
4335  free(buf);
4336 
4337  /* Write direction units. */
4338 
4339  pos = 0;
4340  size = hd.pub.dir_unit_types * hd.dir_unit_size;
4341 
4342  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4343  perror("Allocating unit write buffer");
4344  exit(-1);
4345  }
4346  memset(buf, 0, size);
4347 
4348  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.dir_unit_types; ++i) {
4349  assert(strlen(hd.dir_unit[i]) + 1 <= hd.dir_unit_size);
4350  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.dir_unit[i]);
4351  pos += hd.dir_unit_size;
4352  }
4353 
4354  chk_fwrite(buf, pos, 1, fp);
4355  free(buf);
4356 
4357  /* Write restrictions. */
4358 
4359  pos = 0;
4360  size = hd.max_restriction_types * hd.restriction_size;
4361 
4362  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4363  perror("Allocating restriction write buffer");
4364  exit(-1);
4365  }
4366  memset(buf, 0, size);
4367 
4368  for (i = 0; i < hd.max_restriction_types; ++i) {
4369  if (i == hd.pub.restriction_types) break;
4370  assert(strlen(hd.restriction[i]) + 1 <= hd.restriction_size);
4371  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.restriction[i]);
4372  pos += hd.restriction_size;
4373  }
4374  memcpy(&buf[pos], "__END__", 7);
4375 
4376  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4377  free(buf);
4378 
4379  /* Write tzfiles. */
4380 
4381  pos = 0;
4382  size = hd.max_tzfiles * hd.tzfile_size;
4383 
4384  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4385  perror("Allocating tzfile write buffer");
4386  exit(-1);
4387  }
4388  memset(buf, 0, size);
4389 
4390  for (i = 0; i < hd.max_tzfiles; ++i) {
4391  if (i == hd.pub.tzfiles) break;
4392  assert(strlen(hd.tzfile[i]) + 1 <= hd.tzfile_size);
4393  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.tzfile[i]);
4394  pos += hd.tzfile_size;
4395  }
4396  memcpy(&buf[pos], "__END__", 7);
4397 
4398  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4399  free(buf);
4400 
4401  /* Write countries. */
4402 
4403  pos = 0;
4404  size = hd.max_countries * hd.country_size;
4405 
4406  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4407  perror("Allocating country write buffer");
4408  exit(-1);
4409  }
4410  memset(buf, 0, size);
4411 
4412  for (i = 0; i < hd.max_countries; ++i) {
4413  if (i == hd.pub.countries) break;
4414  assert(strlen(hd.country[i]) + 1 <= hd.country_size);
4415  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.country[i]);
4416  pos += hd.country_size;
4417  }
4418  memcpy(&buf[pos], "__END__", 7);
4419 
4420  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4421  free(buf);
4422 
4423  /* Write datums. */
4424 
4425  pos = 0;
4426  size = hd.max_datum_types * hd.datum_size;
4427 
4428  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4429  perror("Allocating datum write buffer");
4430  exit(-1);
4431  }
4432  memset(buf, 0, size);
4433 
4434  for (i = 0; i < hd.max_datum_types; ++i) {
4435  if (i == hd.pub.datum_types) break;
4436  assert(strlen(hd.datum[i]) + 1 <= hd.datum_size);
4437  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.datum[i]);
4438  pos += hd.datum_size;
4439  }
4440  memcpy(&buf[pos], "__END__", 7);
4441 
4442  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4443  free(buf);
4444 
4445  /* Write legaleses. */
4446 
4447  pos = 0;
4448  size = hd.max_legaleses * hd.legalese_size;
4449 
4450  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4451  perror("Allocating legalese write buffer");
4452  exit(-1);
4453  }
4454  memset(buf, 0, size);
4455 
4456  for (i = 0; i < hd.max_legaleses; ++i) {
4457  if (i == hd.pub.legaleses) break;
4458  assert(strlen(hd.legalese[i]) + 1 <= hd.legalese_size);
4459  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.legalese[i]);
4460  pos += hd.legalese_size;
4461  }
4462  memcpy(&buf[pos], "__END__", 7);
4463 
4464  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4465  free(buf);
4466 
4467  /* Write constituent names. */
4468 
4469  pos = 0;
4470  size = hd.pub.constituents * hd.constituent_size;
4471 
4472  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4473  perror("Allocating constituent write buffer");
4474  exit(-1);
4475  }
4476  memset(buf, 0, size);
4477 
4478  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.constituents; ++i) {
4479  assert(strlen(hd.constituent[i]) + 1 <= hd.constituent_size);
4480  strcpy((NV_CHAR *)&buf[pos], hd.constituent[i]);
4481  pos += hd.constituent_size;
4482  }
4483 
4484  chk_fwrite(buf, pos, 1, fp);
4485  free(buf);
4486 
4487  /* NOTE : Using bit_pack for integers. */
4488 
4489  /* Write speeds. */
4490 
4491  pos = 0;
4492  size = bits2bytes(hd.pub.constituents * hd.speed_bits);
4493 
4494  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4495  perror("Allocating speed write buffer");
4496  exit(-1);
4497  }
4498  memset(buf, 0, size);
4499 
4500  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.constituents; ++i) {
4501  temp_int = NINT(hd.speed[i] * hd.speed_scale) - hd.speed_offset;
4502  assert(temp_int >= 0);
4503  bit_pack(buf, pos, hd.speed_bits, temp_int);
4504  pos += hd.speed_bits;
4505  }
4506 
4507  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4508  free(buf);
4509 
4510  /* Write equilibrium arguments. */
4511 
4512  pos = 0;
4513  size = bits2bytes(hd.pub.constituents * hd.pub.number_of_years *
4514  hd.equilibrium_bits);
4515 
4516  if ((buf = (NV_U_BYTE *)calloc(size, sizeof(NV_U_BYTE))) == NULL) {
4517  perror("Allocating equilibrium write buffer");
4518  exit(-1);
4519  }
4520  memset(buf, 0, size);
4521 
4522  for (i = 0; i < hd.pub.constituents; ++i) {
4523  NV_U_INT32 j;
4524  for (j = 0; j < hd.pub.number_of_years; ++j) {
4525  temp_int = NINT(hd.equilibrium[i][j] * hd.equilibrium_scale) -
4526  hd.equilibrium_offset;
4527  assert(temp_int >= 0);
4528  bit_pack(buf, pos, hd.equilibrium_bits, temp_int);
4529  pos += hd.equilibrium_bits;
4530  }
4531  }
4532 
4533  chk_fwrite(buf, size, 1, fp);
4534  free(buf);
4535 
4536  /* Write node factors. */
4537 
4538  pos = 0;
4539  size =
4540  bits2bytes(hd.pub.constituents * hd.pub.number_of_years * hd.node_bits);
4541
